modules.description: Handles time intervals using seconds and nanoseconds, supporting arithmetic operations like addition and subtraction with normalization. Operates on a private type representing time spans, enabling precise manipulation and comparison. Used for tracking durations in applications requiring high-resolution time calculations, such as performance monitoring or real-time systems.

Provides operations to create, add, subtract, and compare time intervals represented as seconds and microseconds. Works with a private type encapsulating integer-based time values. Enables precise time manipulation in applications requiring timestamp arithmetic, such as logging or performance measurement.

Provides functions to create a time value from individual components, returning None on invalid input, and to compare two time values based on their calendar and clock components. Works with a private type representing a time value structured around date and time fields. Used to validate and order time instances in applications requiring precise time handling.

type t = { it_interval : float; it_value : float } Provides operations to create, manipulate, and query timer specifications with interval and value fields. Works with floating-point values to represent time durations. Used to configure periodic and one-shot timers in real-time applications.

Provides functions to convert between OCaml's `Ptime` type and Unix timestamps, including parsing and formatting time values. Works with 64-bit integer representations of seconds and nanoseconds since the Unix epoch. Enables precise time manipulation in systems requiring interoperability with POSIX-based time APIs.

manages time intervals and values using both integer and floating-point representations, supporting arithmetic, comparison, and validation across different time scales. It includes private types for durations, timestamps, and timer configurations, enabling precise control over time-based operations. Users can perform interval arithmetic, validate time components, and configure timers with customizable intervals and values. Examples include measuring performance, scheduling events, and ensuring accurate time ordering in real-time systems.
